intro: Incarvillea variabilis, commonly known as the variable incarvillea, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, also known as the legume or pea family, and is characterized by its compound leaves and showy, butterfly-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun. Its flowers, which range in color from yellow to orange, are often visited by pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Incarvillea variabilis is a perennial shrub that can reach heights of up to 3 feet, making it a valuable addition to xeriscaped gardens.
